title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìã OVERVIEW
Objective: Master R for data science through collaborative weekly book reviews
Primary Resource: R for Data Science (1st Edition) by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund
Duration: 25 weeks (February 4 ‚Äì July 22, 2026)
Format: 60-minute weekly meetups with rotating leadership
Group Size: 14 participants
Level: Beginner to Intermediate

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üéØ LEARNING GOALS
By the end of this course, participants will be able to:

Import & wrangle data ‚Äì Load, clean, reshape messy datasets into analysis-ready format
Transform & explore ‚Äì Use dplyr to filter, summarize, and join datasets; conduct EDA
Visualize effectively ‚Äì Create exploratory and publication-ready plots with ggplot2
Write functions & automate ‚Äì Build reusable functions; iterate efficiently with purrr
Model data ‚Äì Fit simple and complex models to understand relationships
Communicate results ‚Äì Generate reproducible reports with R Markdown
Apply to epidemiology ‚Äì Use all skills on real STH surveillance and research data

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìö COURSE MATERIALS

Primary Text

R for Data Science (1st Edition) ‚Äì Free online: https://r4ds.hadley.nz
PDF Available: All 24 chapters included in this plan



Secondary References

The Epidemiologist R Handbook ‚Äì Free online: https://www.epirhandbook.com

Domain-specific examples, epi workflows, case studies

Advanced R (2nd Edition) by Hadley Wickham ‚Äì Free online: https://adv-r.hadley.nz

Deep-dive on functions, vectors, environments, metaprogramming




Required Software

R (latest version): https://cloud.r-project.org
RStudio IDE: https://www.rstudio.com/download

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìñ BOOK ORDER vs.¬†OUR LEARNING SEQUENCE

Why We‚Äôre Reordering the Chapters
The R for Data Science book is published in this order: Visualization (Ch 1) ‚Üí Transformation (Ch 3) ‚Üí Wrangling (Ch 7‚Äì13) ‚Üí Programming (Ch 14‚Äì17) ‚Üí Modeling (Ch 18‚Äì20) ‚Üí Communication (Ch 21‚Äì24).
However, this order isn‚Äôt optimal for beginners learning epidemiology. The book‚Äôs authors acknowledge this in their Preface:

‚ÄúStarting with data ingest and tidying is suboptimal because 80% of the time it‚Äôs routine and boring, and the other 20% of the time it‚Äôs weird and frustrating. That‚Äôs a bad place to start learning a new subject! Instead, we‚Äôll start with visualization and transformation of data that‚Äôs already been imported and tidied.‚Äù

The problem: Chapter 1 (ggplot2) assumes clean data exists. But beginners need to import, clean, and reshape data FIRST before they can visualize or analyze it.


Our Reordered Learning Sequence
We follow the natural real-world epidemiological workflow instead of the book‚Äôs ordering:





Phase
Weeks
Our.Order
Book.Chapters
Purpose




1. Foundation
1‚Äì3
First
2, 4, 6 (Workflow)
Learn RStudio, organize work, set up projects BEFORE coding


2. Wrangling
4‚Äì13
Second
7‚Äì13 (Import, Tidy, Transform, Join, Handle types)
Get messy data into analysis-ready format


3. Exploration
14‚Äì15
Third
5, 1 (EDA, Visualization)
Explore clean data visually & statistically


4. Programming
16‚Äì18
Fourth
15, 16, 17 (Functions, Vectors, Iteration)
Write reusable code & automate workflows


5. Modeling
19‚Äì21
Fifth
18, 19, 20 (Model Basics, Building, Many Models)
Fit & evaluate statistical models


6. Communication
22‚Äì25
Sixth
21‚Äì24 (R Markdown, Graphics, Formats, Workflow)
Document findings & create reproducible reports









Why This Order Works Better
‚úÖ Motivation: Learn foundational tools first, then apply them to real problems
‚úÖ Real-world: Follow the actual epidemiological analysis workflow
‚úÖ Practical: Work with messy data early; clean it before analyzing
‚úÖ Confidence: See tangible results at each step (import ‚Üí clean ‚Üí analyze ‚Üí visualize)
‚úÖ Less frustration: Don‚Äôt start with ‚Äúboring‚Äù wrangling; build to it naturally


Book Order (As Published)
For reference, here‚Äôs the original chapter sequence in R for Data Science (1st Edition):

Part
Title

I: Explore
Data Visualization with ggplot2


2

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üéì WEEKLY MEETING FORMAT (60 Minutes)

Structure





Time
Activity
Details




0‚Äì15 min
Summary & Discussion
Leader(s) summarize key concepts & learning objectives; group discusses what was clear/confusing and what's relevant to epi work


15‚Äì45 min
Live Demo, Exercises & Problem-Solving
Leader(s) demonstrate 2‚Äì3 code examples live; group follows along, attempts exercises, asks questions in real-time


45‚Äì55 min
Help & Troubleshooting
Leader(s) & peers help resolve coding errors, confusions, and remaining questions


55‚Äì60 min
Wrap-up & Next Week Preview
Summarize key takeaways; preview next week's chapter; assign prep work









Leader Responsibilities
Each leader should: - Read chapter thoroughly 1 week in advance (3‚Äì4 hours) - Prepare 2‚Äì3 worked code examples to demo live (copy-paste ready) - Identify 3‚Äì5 key concepts that will be discussed - Note common confusions or tricky sections from your own reading - Bring 2‚Äì3 discussion questions to engage the group - Help troubleshoot participant questions & coding errors - Share practical epi applications of the chapter content
For Co-Leaders (3 toughest sessions): - Divide responsibilities: One leads first half, other leads second half
- Coordinate prep work: Meet 1 week before to align on content & demos - Share code examples: Create demo scripts together for consistency


Leadership Rotation (Random Selection by Number 1‚Äì14)
To assign leaders randomly: 1. Each person selects a number between 1 and 14 at the start of the course 2. Leadership follows the rotation below across all 25 sessions

Toughest sessions (2 leads each): Apr 1 (Session 9): #9 & #10 co-lead (Pipes - Ch 14) Jun 3 (Session 18): #5 & #6 co-lead (Iteration - Ch 17) Jul 1 (Session 22): #11 & #12 co-lead (R Markdown - Ch 21) Perfect balance: 14 leads √ó 2 sessions each = exactly 25 sessions covered!

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìù WEEKLY PREPARATION (~4 hours)
Participants should dedicate approximately 4 hours per week:

Before the Meeting (3.5 hours)

Read & understand chapter (2 hours)

Skim introduction for context (15 min)
Read thoroughly with code examples (1 hr)
Run all examples in RStudio (45 min)

Take notes on key concepts (15 min)

Practice exercises (1 hour)

Work through 5‚Äì7 exercises at chapter end
Run code locally; save working examples
Debug errors independently first
Note 2‚Äì3 challenges for discussion

Prepare questions & review (30 minutes)

List 2‚Äì3 specific questions
Review epi applications from syllabus
Preview next week‚Äôs chapter overview




After the Meeting (30 minutes)

Review meeting notes & code demos
Re-run 1‚Äì2 examples from leader
Update personal code library

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
ü§ù GROUP GUIDELINES

Expectations

Attend weekly meetings: In-person or virtual, same time each week
Complete prep work: Read chapter & attempt exercises before meeting
Participate actively: Share insights, ask questions, help peers
Lead 2‚Äì3 chapters: Fulfill your leadership duties when assigned (solo or co-lead)
Respect others: Patient with different learning paces & backgrounds



Communication

WhatsApp channel: Share resources, ask quick questions between meetings
Google Drive folder: Store notes, code, datasets
Meeting notes: Record key takeaways & useful code snippets each week

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìû SUPPORT & RESOURCES

If You Get Stuck

Google the error message ‚Äì Often finds solutions quickly
Search Stack Overflow ‚Äì Add [R] tag for R-specific results
Consult secondary references:

Epidemiologist R Handbook: https://www.epirhandbook.com
Advanced R: https://adv-r.hadley.nz

Ask the group: Bring confusing sections to weekly meetings
WhatsApp channel: Post quick questions between meetings



Helpful Links

R Project: https://www.r-project.org
RStudio Download: https://www.rstudio.com
Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org
R4DS Online: https://r4ds.hadley.nz
RStudio Community: https://community.rstudio.com
Stack Overflow [R] tag: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/r

‚úÖ CHECKLIST FOR GETTING STARTED
Before Week 1 (by February 04, 2026):

Install R (latest version)
Install RStudio IDE
Test RStudio: Open it, run 1 + 1 in console
Read Chapter 2 (Workflow: Basics) for first meeting (Leader #1)

title: R for Data Science: Complete Study Plan & Syllabus
text:
üìñ FINAL NOTES
This syllabus provides a structured path to mastery of R for epidemiological data science. The key to success is:

Consistency: Show up weekly & do the prep work
Curiosity: Ask questions; try variations of examples
Collaboration: Learn from peers; help each other
Application: Apply concepts to your own epi data

By Week 25, you‚Äôll have the skills to conduct independent, reproducible epidemiological analyses from raw data to publication-ready reports.
